thread.title: 7 things to know about today, plus CenturyLink cutting jobs
thread.title_full: 7 things to know about today, plus CenturyLink cutting jobs

author: Cindy Barth
title: 7 things to know about today, plus CenturyLink cutting jobs
text: 7 things to know about today, plus CenturyLink cutting jobs Aug 10, 2015, 7:26am EDT Industries & Tags Cindy Barth Editor Orlando Business Journal Home of the Day Kathleen Lavine | Denver Business Journal CenturyLink network technician Dale Herbert splices and places fiber-optic cable for… more CenturyLink Inc. said it will cut 1,000 positions out of 44,000 companywide. The telecom hasn't said how many of those cuts will be in Florida. "We don’t have specific impacts by community and/or by state at this time," CenturyLink spokeswoman Annmarie Sartor told the Monroe (Louisiana) News-Star newspaper in the company's headquarters city. In CenturyLink's disappointing second-quarter earnings report Wednesday , in which the company's earnings fell below its own and Wall Street analysts' expectations, CEO Glen Post cited "continued pressure on wholesale revenues and higher employee and benefit costs. While we are disappointed with the financial results for this quarter, we are positioning CenturyLink to drive stronger sales, strategic revenue growth and improved operating cash flow in the months ahead.” Read more here from the Denver Business Journal. And be sure to check out these other Monday headlines: Daytona Rising on track for January opening The $400 million Daytona Rising project , encompassing Daytona International Speedway's front stretch, is about 85 percent complete and on track for its January completion, the Daytona Beach News-Journal reports . The Jan. 30-31 Rolex 24 at Daytona will be the first event with full use of the new facility, which is expected to transform the speedway into the world's first motorsports stadium, with premium amenities and attractions. Trump reality check Here's an interesting note from sister paper South Florida Business Journal and its editor, Al Lewis . Donald Trump talked a big game last week when he boasted that he has "bought" his fellow presidential candidates in the past. Yahoo Finance columnist Rick Newman took at look at the numbers. He's given $10,000 to Scott Walker , $2,500 to Mike Huckabee and $500 to Jeb Bush . He's also given $8,500 to Hilary Clinton . So, if that's all it take to buy a politician these days, America has quite a sale going on. Click here to read Newman's take. Sen. Bill Nelson hammers airlines A report by the staff of Sen. Bill Nelson (D-Fla.), the ranking Democrat on the Senate Commerce Committee, calls for a crackdown on undisclosed airline fees. The profits, Nelson told News 13, are so high they're prompting an investigation of the commercial flight industry. The Nelson-commissioned study found that the airline industry collected more than $38 billion in fees above and beyond ticket prices in 2014. Click here to read more . New Stetson University Water Institute names executive director Stetson University selected noted environmentalist and policy expert Clay Henderson as the first executive director of its newly established Institute for Water and Environmental Resilience. The institute is expected to bring together faculty and student research in collaboration with community partners to look at big-picture issues affecting the environment. It will include all Stetson colleges and campuses. For the last 15 years, Henderson has been senior counsel at the national law firm of Holland & Knight, focusing on environmental law and water law. Before that, he served as president of The Florida Audubon Society, one of the nation's oldest conservation organizations. He also has worked for The Nature Conservancy and the Trust for Public Land.
